body.p:
Rev. S. Morais
My dear Sir

I have your favor of
the 12th of last month. Only this evening I could man
age to attend to my correspondence, which, for the last
three weeks had been sadly neglected. I am, in the lan
guage of an old Presbyterian friend of mine a "muchly
worked"¬ù man. My literary engagements require almost
all my day-hours, and I was much as working for Jew
ish papers is like working [Hebrew] I do a little
extra work for southern papers and magazines so as to
earn money for books, of which I have now a considerable
number, including the first four vols. of the new [Hebrew],
which is a beauty. In addition I prepare my sermons,
read modern literature and study. I have during the
past month studied Jesaja[?] 48-53 with critical notes
of my own composition; read ten pages in [Hebrew]; also
in [Hebrew] the weekly chapters and found time
to write read Kayserling's Life of Mendelssohn, Hensel's
"Mendelssohn family"¬ù and four chapters of the
eleventh volume of Graetz' history of the Jews.
The latter three works I needed for a course of

Friday evening lectures I am now delivering before my
congregation on the "history of the Jews from 1750-1880."¬ù
The life of Mendelssohn formed the special theme
for the last four weeks. Were it not for the [?]
ions of my professional calling, I could write and
study more. I will not travel this winter; I need all
my time for my congregation and my own improvement.

I have not yet received the volumes of the [Hebrew],
but I enclose three dollars, which I beg you to place
to my account for their eventual arrival I am
indeed anxious for a closer acquaintance with this
wonderful [Hebrew].

I have been painfully surprised at Mr. Ben
jamin's inaugural. I said [Hebrew]
We live no longer in the age of hobbies; we are in
the age of distinction and God only knows when the
building up will commence. I begin more and more
to perceive the stupendous blender of rapid
transit theology and my change of opinion is
cognizable in the earnest, moderate and conservative

I beg you to note the difference in dates between the
first and third pages of this letter. At the close of the
second page I was interrupted whilst writing it, and
until this minute found no time to finish it. I mailed you
last week two copies of the Visitor and I will esteem it a
favor if you will give me your criticism upon its cont
ents. Now, dear Sir, I come to you for advice [Hebrew]
[Hebrew]. There is some trouble here, of which the
main burden falls on my shoulders, and I hardly know
which way to turn, for the simple reason that the matter
is one of policy, not of [Hebrew]. The case is substant
ially as follows: A man, who for many years had
borne a good reputation, became a criminal. He
is a widower, has two children, a boy and girl. In his
sister's house he seduced a servant girl, a gentile,
of dubious character, and was, upon her complaint,
indited by the grand jury for seduction. This crime
is punishable in this state with penitentiary
for no less than two and no more than ten years

The man, who is a member of my congregation, became
alarmed, and after the girl had given birth to a male
child, he married her, thus quashing the indictment
against him. Then my troubles commenced. Three weeks
ago the new mistress, made a wife by force of law
or fear of punishment, presented herself to me with
the request to be made—a Jewess! I received her
kindly, spoke of the difficulties connected with such
an act, in short evaded an answer, mainly to gain
time. Let me say here, that I am, and have always
been, bitterly opposed to proselytizing. Especially
have I a horror of making a Jew or Jewess out of
such, whose carnal inclinations simply bring them
to become yoke-fellows of members of our race.
Excepting once in Philadelphia, when on the Board
of Ministers, I never engaged in such work. Five
applied to me in Texas, and I invariably refused
them; they went to other cities where, for a fee, the
minister converted and married them the
same hour. Yet, I am conscious that occasion

may arise, when such an act would be a wise poli
cy. In the present case, I have been thinking, that
this woman, though she was little less than a courtesan
([Hebrew]), being now the legally married wife of a Hebrew,
and having the care of two Jewish children, who at
tend my Sabbath schools besides her own boy, whom
his father has also been [Hebrew] upon the
mother promising that she would raise him as a
Jew, I say, I have been thinking that the act
of formally making her a Jewess might encourage
her to do a mother's duty by these children. I have
thus expressed myself to the husband, without at
all agreeing or promising or specifying a time
to do the act. But now come the ladies of his
family, sisters and sisters-in-law, ladies of most
excellent standing in the community, exemplary
Jewesses and faithful workers, and just vow, that
they will leave the congregation in case this wo
man enters our ranks. They have sternly set their
face against their brother. My prayers, protestations

have been of no avail, and I need to have a great
deal of influence with them. The question now is:
what is my duty? Shall I follow my judgement and
only for the purpose of saving these children, make the
woman a Jewess, or shall I suffer prejudice, no matter
how well founded, to interfere and refuse to accede
to the request? I cannot give myself an answer, and
I look anxiously for advice from you. Pending
your answer things are in status quo.

I have other matters to inform you about, but I will
not tire you. This letter is too long already. Hoping
you will answer soon I remain
